Their food is quite delicious and fresh. It's well-spiced, and the lamb dishes are especially good. It's definitely quality Indian food with none of that greasiness that you find in lesser places. However, I think we'll stick to takeout in the future, because it's not a fun dine-in experience.
author: Alyssa S.

description:
My girlfriend and myself were highly dismayed after reading that our favorite indian resturant in the lower hate was under new ownership.

Little did we know that our previous chef had moved closer to our place!

We have a soft spot for chicken tiki masala and goat cheese naan which were both wonderful here (but a bit pricey on the cheese naan). 

Take out was ready quickly, very hot, and had a large excess of sauce for later consumption.

Great find and we'll be back soon.
author: Brent M.

description: If this restaurant was charging what places like Pakwan, Shalimar and Naan N Curry charge, then I wouldn't have thought twice about my experience....though based on their prices, we expected a lot more. We got our food about 2 minutes after we ordered....which makes me question how freshly made the food was. The Saag Paneer came out barely warm, the naan came out late and the waitstaff wasn't super attentive. With Udupi Palace and Dosa right next door, I probably wont be giving this spot a second try.
author: Todd L.

description: Just ok. Prices were a bit high fot mediocre indian food. Service was very good thing though.
author: LT B.

description:
5 stars based on the Chicken Tikki Masala alone. Its the BLT of the indian food world. I made that up so if you dont like bacon then im sorry.

My friends also loved their food but I dont know what they got.

The garlic Naan rocks as do the samosas. 

$20 each total without a drink. Not bad.
author: Michael D.

description:
We came here for dinner at 8pm on a Saturday.  A party of 4, we were seated relatively quickly even though we had no reservations and the place looked pretty full.

I'm don't know much about Indian food other than they usually ask you how hot you want your meal on an arbitrary, but seemingly scientific scale (1-10, mild/medium/hot, etc.).  Anyways, it tasted good to me.  The Chicken Tikka Masala (which I understand is a "wuss" on the 1-10 scale) had me wiping up every last drop of the sauce.  The garlic naan was  perfectly crispy and chewy at the same time, great for dipping.

As for price, It was about $25/person for ordering an entree each, 4 portions of rice, 2 naan, and drinks.  Totally reasonable, totally good for a casual dinner on a Saturday night or any night.  There were several tables of 10+ people, so you could definitely bring a whole reunion dinner or the like.
author: Zhi Q.

description:
On a recent visit to SF, my brother and I decided to eat at Aslam's Rasoi.

Food - very good fare for a decent price.  Appetizers are decently priced and on a par with or better than the higher end Indian food eateries in NYC.  Entrees were well made and tasty and reasonably priced.  (lots of vegetarian options and they will adjust spicyness on request)

Atmosphere - I liked this place quite a bit.  One could easily see that it was trying to distinguish itself from the faster sort of Indian or Pakistani food one finds in New York or other cities.  However, in doing so, they didn't go so terribly overboard that high end ambiance became a theme.  It's comfortable without being too casual or too staunchly modern.

Service - our waitress was friendly and informative and didn't try any upselling or pushing the specials.  Overall I was very satisfied with the service.

I would definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for a good, comfortable bite in the Mission area.
author: Thomas A.

description: Hands down my favorite place in the city for Indian/Pakistani food. The service is awesome and the wait staff are all so friendly, I always leave with a smile on my face.
author: A C.

description:
Like everyone else I am sort of confuse with the negative reviews. I know the ownership recently changed and Aslam (the chef) converted Rasoi to Aslam's Rasoi, and has done a very good job about it. 

Have been here three times now, and each time both food and service has been excellent. Tandoori chicken and palak paneer are two of my favorite things in the menu. You would want to get  one of the three tables in the parlour for a lovely evening. 

And last  but not the least for desert, take my word and go for the Kulfi. Oh my god, it is sooooo goood.
author: Shradha K.

description: Best India food restaurant in the whole bay area. I've been there multiple times and never disappointed. Great food and excellent customer service... what more can u ask for.
author: Adi K.

description:
Don't get me wrong. The food is great. That is not the problem. If I could give this place a rating for the food, itd probably get 4 to 4.5 stars. 

The service and set up for the place is really bad though. It looks classy enough when you get in, but the staff is really disorganized and the tables are really bizarrely placed; some of the 2-tops had an L-configuration for the seating instead of the two chairs facing each other. There were no hostesses (at least when we went) nor any sign-in sheet to tell who came first, so of the 10-12 of us waiting, no one really knew who was next. One of the waiters told us that we can all just sort it out ourselves....

we were sat in a 2 top that was booth-seat on one side and the chair was put in an L-configuration on the left, (so we werent facing each other). we were right next to the kitchen which has a window so you can peak into the kitchen-- which I suppose they think is a novelty. but the lights from the kitchen were really bright and harsh and came down on my eyes (I was sitting in the chair) so we ended up both sitting side-by-side on the booth side of the table, with our backs towards the kitchen window.

from there the service wasnt terrible. it took a while for water to come, but thats it. 

Again, the food was great. I generally dont like heavy curries, as they often taste very similar. but these tasted quite nice. the chicken tikka masala had a nice smokey flavor to it. the only issue is that they didnt have the red onion chutney, whihc is bizarre. most indian places do....

i would recommend coming at a not-so-busy time, as they clearly can't handle themselves during busy times.
author: Sumeet S.

description:
My friends and I agree.  This place is some of the best Indian/Pakistani food.
I've never been disappointed and always more than satisfied.
It's family run so the service is as personal as it gets.
author: Oren F.

description:
Aslam is the best cook ever!!!!! I cannot compare this indian/pakistani restaurant to any other restaurant out there. I've eaten everything, everything on the menu and still have not been disappointed. 

I've only eaten in the restaurant twice so I cannot make this review on service,
author: Favi R.

description:
This place Just reopened under new ownership. Many of the old problems persist, particulary with the food. Simply put, seekers of all things mediocre will not be disappointed. Appetizers and entrees range from "thank you for nothing" to someplace right close to average. 

The service is better than average. Points for effort. 

I'd still recommend Dosa, notwithstanding the wait--which can, and quiite often does, make time in Beckett's "Godot" feel like light speed.
author: Michael P.

description:
Aslam's is my absolute favorite Indian restaurant, and even though I'm no longer living in San Francisco, it's well worth the drive! Parking can be a bit of a pain, but there's a pretty cheap lot nearby, and it's just a few blocks from the 24/ Mission BART and MUNI station. I've had two birthdays here, and both times they were very accommodating to my large group, even adding more chairs as unexpected guests showed up. Another time, I brought my dad and his out-of-state girlfriend, and even though we arrived half an hour before they opened for dinner, they rushed out as we were about to go wait somewhere else, brought us in from the cold, and took our orders, bringing us our food impressively fast for somewhere that wasn't even supposed to be open! The servers are so nice and friendly here that I always wonder if they remember me from last time, even though I don't come here often enough for that to be the case. 

Despite being so great with large groups, it's intimate and sweet for a date or catching up with a friend. And the food! I've never had a clunker here, and I've tried paneer, chicken, lamb, fish, different kinds of naan, rice, etc... The mango lassi is the best I've ever had, and my favorite food items are the goat cheese naan, the garlic naan, the fish pakoras, and the lamb rogan josh, which is always tender and never gamey. Even my dad, who normally isn't a big fan of Indian food, loved this; it's not your typical greasy Indian buffet fare.  What's more, half the time I've been here, they've brought some little dessert treat with the check, which always makes me feel welcome. It's been great for my vegetarian friends as well, for what it's worth (although most Indian places are!).  It's a little pricier than some other good Indian places in the area, but I think that the food here is noticeably better, the atmosphere is really cute, and the service is top notch; you get what you pay for! Give it a try, this is one of my favorite restaurants in the city, and definitely my favorite Indian food in the Bay.
author: Sarah M.

description: My fav Indian food in SF. Excellent service and great location. Highly recommended!
author: Stephen S.

description: Maybe our meal was so bad because we were the last people in the place, but it was REALLY bad.  Won't be going back when there are so many other great Indian places in the city.
author: Jennifer N.

description:
I had dinner at Aslam's Rasoi three times in one week.  This is not my usual behavior.  While I am a creature of habit, three times in one week??  I love this place.

More specifically, I love their saag paneer.  The paneer is delicate and amazing, the spinach spicy and flavorful and creamy-licious.  The naan is delicious.  I've also tried their prawns vindaloo and a fish dish.  All quite tasty.

I had the same waiter each time.  He remembered me on the second visit, and was smiling and friendly from the start - as was the rest of the staff.  He even remembered how spicy I liked my food.

Too bad I already ate dinner tonight . . . I will be back soon . . .
author: Pam M.

description:
First of all...Order the lamb chops...they are incredible...well seasoned and tender.  You won't be sorry.

Their food is much better than most of the Indian/Pakistani places.  Even the standard dishes, Chicken Korma, curries are more interesting and flavorful.  The owners and servers are incredibly nice....they make the whole experience outstanding.
author: Puff G.

description:
So, ok, I lived in London for three years.  And I like Indian food.  A lot.  I ate it probably once a week, on average, while living in London, where it is arguably the best cuisine option in town (without spending your entire day's earnings on dinner).

So I wanted to love this place.  I live around the corner, it's my "local" (if you don't count the divine, but very different, Dosa, up the street).

But after I ate here, my dining companion actually said "someone should burn that place down just to keep innocent people from having to eat that excuse for food."  Seriously the worst Indian meal either of us had ever had.  It all tasted like someone in the kitchen was playing a joke, heating freezer-burned vegetables and slopping them in with canned sauces and charging $12 for the "dish."  That is the only excuse for the quality of the meal we had--it must be reheated packaged stuff.  Because if someone is making that stuff from scratch, they need to be ashamed.  And if they're not, they need to lower their dang prices to reflect the freezer-burn of their meat/veg.  The chicken was tough and stringy, the samosas tasted like cardboard, the CTM was oily and bland, and the service was laughably slow and unorganized.

The saddest part is that we paid $80 for dinner for two and this was not exactly a feast - just rice, naan, chicken korma, chicken tikka masala, saag paneer, samosas, a glass of  house wine each and chutney (which they charge for!).  For $80 two can eat at Range up the street and have one of the best meals in the Mission.  Or across the street at the usually awesome Spork.  So it is insult to injury that not only is the food at this place pretty awful, but the prices are high.

I can never figure out why this place is usually so busy, nor how it has so many glowing reviews here.  Perhaps our meal was an abberation--I can only hope so--perhaps my standards are too high (I highly doubt that...I mean, I love me some Naan-n-Curry)--but I won't ever be back to Rasoi.

If you're in the mood for Indian, but want it actually to be tasty and fresh, try Chutney for the classics or Dosa for something new.
author: Marie S.

description: Pretty tasty north indian food - excellent naans and kulchas too.
author: M B.

description: LOVE Aslam's Rasoi!  They make the yummiest bengen bartha in the city and the garlic basil naan is delish!  Aasif, the owner's son who greets you upon arrival has the best energy in the city.  This restaurant is full of heart and warms the soul.  Eat here!
author: Debbie S.

description: Came here on a whim one Sunday night. We were greeted and seated immediately by a really friendly young chap. Our party was a bit indecisive, so he recommended us a third entree, which we ended up taking. Got some apps, one scallop and two veggie entrees, with rice and bread, and a bottle of wine. Food was pretty excellent, perfect for the evening, and the service was friendly and impeccable. The young sir even got the door for us on the way out. In the end, I wasn't able to fault them a single thing. I'll certainly be heading back.
author: Dean W.

description:
Bombay Pakoras were a bountiful basket of love in the form of fried. This appetizer and a tap beer ($5) would make a nice happy hour...will make a nice happy hour, as I will be back some Friday night with friends.

Ordered both chicken bhartha ($11) and eggplant bhartha ($10). This was my mistake - I mean, I love bhartha (who wouldn't with all the mushy spicy eggplanty goodness?). Ugh, we realized the mistake only when the food arrived, and ordered another dish (and took the chicken bhartha to go). 

Though this was my error, I think a better waitress would have been on the ball enough to check if I really intended to order two practically identical dishes.

Our replacement chicken dish was chicken madras ($12). The meat in both chicken dishes was tender and flavorful, a nice mix of dark and white meat. Medium spiciness was pretty tingly.

We also ordered paratha ($3) which was flaky and buttery and, on a lark, Goat Cheese Naan ($5) which was a decent snack, but not in an Indian restaurant - the flavors were just off. I must mention the highlight was the raita ($3), the thickest and best raita in SF, a land where raita is usually a watered down mockery of yogurt curd.

With one order of rice, chai, tax, tip and a couple of beers we broke $70 (with leftovers for two lunches). That's running on the almost too expensive side - in particular, the vegetarian dishes are $2 too expensive ($8 lentils? C'mon!)

But, ignoring fiscal issues and focusing on  flavor, Rasoi now may be one of my favorite North Indian restaurants in SF, I'll be heading back to double-check.
author: Lauren G.

description:
So, not many restaurants are open New Year's Day.  I understand that.  Even given that, our experience at Aslam's Rasoi was pretty ridiculous.   We waited over an hour for our food, for no apparent reason.  The restaurant was busy when we arrived, but had nearly completely cleared out by the time the food was on our table.  People who ordered after us had finished and paid by the time our food arrived.  My point being:  I was ridiculously hungry and cranky by the time the food arrived.

Food itself:  kinda enh.  We ordered the assorted bread basket, and that I would recommend.  The naan (various varieties) here is GOOD.  The bengan bhartha left a LOT to be desired - just kind of insipid.  The curries we ordered (prawn korma, murgh makhani) were super-rich and decent.  However, for the price, SMALL portions.
author: maisnon ..

description:
This is the best Indian/Pakistani restaurant I've ever been to.  The waiters were super friendly and attentive.  Plus the food was delicious.  This is a treat cause it is kind of expensive.

Samosas

Two crisp and spiced vegetable puffs filled w/ potatoes, peas & Spices  $5

I was trying to go to the menu to see what we had but i don't remember the exact names.

We also had spinach chicken, a chicken dish with pineapple and coconut milk, a rice dish w/almonds, and this paneer special where the cheese blocks were covered in that red sauce... omg it was soo good.

Then we had this dessert of mango yogurt.  All of it was an orgasm in my mouth.
author: Sabrina A.

description: Not worth the price at all. Their naan was okay type but stay FAR FAR AWAY from their chicken biryani.
author: Mekhala M.

description: I've been here three times and I've never been disappointed! The first time I came here was for a friend's birthday and I was so impressed with the waiters that I came back the very next week on a date. At my friend's birthday the waiters brought us complimentary champagne and they were extremely attentive and friendly! Also, the food is wonderful and very fresh. The last time I was there I tried their seafood curry and loved it, I tried my friend's tofu dish. I love the complexity of the flavors in their dishes and I also love that their dishes are not too spicy, too creamy nor are they too greasy.
author: Natalie M.

description: The prices for items on the dinner menu are on the higher side. The taste is strictly OK nothing to rave about. The service is ok. The biryani was something of a pulao kind with tomatoes which you dont see in biryani.
author: Sia R.

description:
Admittedly I only ever order appetizers, Saag Paneer and a Lassi, but for those three things I am a connoisseur. The food here is good, albeit on the rich/creamy/heavy side. It also can be pretty bland - but I can be pretty white about that anyway, so it's all good to me. 

Inevitably I get an entree, have about three bites of it and take the rest home since its so rich. But it's still excellent the next day... and the next.

Another selling point about this place is that it is big and almost always empty, especially compared to Dosa, which is down the street. And there are no hipsters trying to be 'cultural.' The waitstaff has always been nice and the food prompt. 

So, yes, this is a no nonsense indian food place that isn't really trying to be anything else.
author: Gabe S.

description:
Update: Since my initial review I have been back here 2-3 more times. I can now be confident in saying that this is THE BEST indian/pakistani food in the city!!
--------------------------------------------

Frankly I don't understand the negative reviews...

If you want trendy then go to Dosa; if you want high quality fantastic pakistani/indian food, with nice friendly service, then go to Aslam's Rasoi! Aslam, the chef/owner of this family owned and run restaurant, has been a chef at many well known restaurants including Indian Oven and Rottee.

We wnet early last night which gave us a chance to chat with the whole family. I've never met such genuine people in my life.

Now the food...yummmmmmy!!! My wife and I love indian/pakistani food and have tried just about any restaurant in the bay area. This is one of the best! First off, the ingredients are high quality and fresh. We tried the Sikh Kabob which was THE BEST we've had anywhere. The ground lamb is not the low quality stuff you may find at some of the places in the tenderloin. High quality, fresh goround lamb, perfectly seasoned. We also tried the assorted appetizers, chicken vindaloo, a mixed vegetable dish that was made with cream, fresh frruit, and nuts, assorted naan basket, and basmati rices. EVERYTHING was very well done! For desert we had golab jamon and rice pudding, on the house, and both were freshly made and delicious.

See, I used to live in london and kind of spoiled when it comes to indian/pakistani food. This restaurant is the first restaurant in the bay area that comes very close to the indian food in england.

I can say with confidence that we've found are favorite pakistani/indian restaurant and we will go back many many times.

Good job Aslam...delicious food!
author: Reza E.

description:
Preface: I've been here three times, always as part of a prearranged party of 10+, always with the food having been ordered for me.

That said: I always leave full, buzzed and happy, with my tongue slightly on fire, the way I like it.

The samosas are great, as are the dal, various curries, and garlic naan. Make sure you like garlic if you order that last one, there are fist-sized chunks of garlic on top. The drinks/wine list is pretty extensive and we've always gotten good pairing recommendations from the staff. 

Some dishes could be a little subtler flavor-wise, but overall this is a good bet for parties of any size.
author: andy d.

description:
I have been here a few times now and each time, I am left with the feeling of wanting to come back. The service is pleasant. The food and delicious and the wait is zip, zap, zero. 

That's right, if you are craving Indian food in the Mission and don't want to wait for a table at the other place a block away, come here.

Last time we went, the place was packed and our food took a little longer than usual to get to our table. To make up for it, our server brought us tasty Mango Lassi shots. Yes!! We will be back!!

Minus one star because it's a bit pricey, but so is everything else these days.
author: Kathleen N.

description: Four smaller sized people were served four large plates of delicious Indian food. All became quiet. Shortly thereafter, all four plates were empty. Enough said.
author: Mrs. M.

description: Couldn't get into Dosa's at the right time so we came here.  No wait and were seated right away.  THey have a lot of non-Indian beer on tap although we ordered a couple of bottles of Taj Mahal.  We next ordered dinner and it showed up in like 3 minutes which made me a little concerned.  I had the chicken Tikka Masala and it was just OK nothing to right home about.
author: Mark M.

description:
I'm not rating this restaurant a 5 star because it's a posh, fancy, expensive place.  

I'm rating it a 5 star because it has some of the best Indian food I've had in CA.  I've always loved Indian food.  I spent a bit of time in England.  And enjoyed some very good curries while I was there. Plus I love good a good sauce of any nationality.  And Indian sauces are some of the best. :)  And I've had many different dishes here and really enjoyed them all.  And the naan bread....soooooo good.  Always made fresh and served hot.

Top it off with good service and great rice* and it doesn't get much better.

I know raving about the rice seems a bit off.  But their rice is perfect every time....not to dry, not to clumpy....just right.
author: Joe P.

description:
Is it possible to give a place 9 stars?  We are never disappointed with this place and are always surprised that we can walk right in.  I love that.  When I get hungry I've got no patience for waiting.

The staff is always friendly and helpful.  The food is great, you can get the spiciest Indian food I have found in San Francisco (just ask them).

Everything is delicious and there is a parking garage around the corner.
author: Tom Y.

description: Friendly, roomy spot with warm interior.  The hosts and servers are very friendly and suggest house specialties.  The menu is large, and all the items were ordered were delicious.  This will be our go-to place for Indian food.
author: John K.

description: This place is probably our favorite Indian restaurant.  The naan and kulcha is delicious.  The Shish Kebab is always moist.  And the Chicken Tikka Masala is wonderful.   The staff is always great and the atmosphere is better than most Indian restaurants.
author: Ed J.

description:
Being used to getting getting my Indian fix from the TL (among other fixes..), I was ill-prepared for the posh ambiance of Aslam Rasoi. "Gettin' jiggy with it" was playing as I walked in. Excellent. Nothing I like more than rappers turned actors rapping. 

This is the only place I've ever enjoyed Saag Paneer. The cheese is firm and flavorful instead of tasting like spinach. I never order tandoori anything for fear I'll be forced to nourish myself on dried out carcass. To my surprise, the tandoori chicken was incredibly moist and flavorful. 

I'll be back when I just want Indian food-the crack in the Mission doesn't compare the TL variety.
author: Monica L.

description: Aslam's Rasio is always tasty and the wait staff friendly and helpful. I would especially recommend the pork chops but also love the vegetarian options. Yum.
author: Susan E.

description:
Slightly torn here... came here with two friends and we decided to go family style. We ordered plain naan, onion kulcha and the appetizer plate (which came with samosas, pakora, and papadum). Everything was well portioned for two people, not so much for three, meaning not quite family friendly servings. Plus just having to order plain naan is odd to me, but I'm not going to dock them for that. The onion kulcha was delicious with the raita and the naan.. well that was normal. We split the samosas and pakora but at least I can say I walked away knowing the pakora was good, can't really say the samosa impressed me.

We ordered the chana masala, lamb korma, and half tandoori chicken all at medium (we asked for pepper on the side). The food came out without the pepper on the side so my roommate who adores hot foods had to wait and the waitress had to be reminded to bring it out. I am generally not a fan of tandoori chicken but it was well prepared, tender, and overall good. Chana masala was decent with some good notes to it but I was sort of sad with the lamb korma. That plate came out with a few pieces of lamb which made us all wonder what would have happened if we did individual plates (someone would be starving). The korma itself was bland so I was grateful when the pepper arrived to give it that extra push.

On the bright side the waitress was accommodating when we requested wine and brought two tasters for us to decide upon. After the meal she brought us a shot of mango lassi which was delicious. So the service was great but the dishes were just not that impressive.
author: Shauna S.

description:
Top marks for atmosphere and presentation of food. 

Food & Drink

We ordered a mango lassi which was one of the best I've ever had. For mains we ordered a murgh masala (chicken) and paneer tikka masala. Both tasted incredible though we ordered medium spice and the chicken was perfect but the paneer was definitely on the hot side. I mentioned this to the waiter as she has asked how eveyrthing was, she promptly brought over some raita to cool things down which helped. 
We also ordered some chapatis and rice. The chapati was fluffly and had a great tandoor oven smoky flavour. 

Service

In the beginning she was very quick and came a number of times to our table to see if we had decided but after the food was brought over (very quick), service was impossibly slow. It took them a very long time to clear our plates and bring our bill which we had to ask for a couple of times. 

I really wish restaurants would implement a simple little discreet call button at the table (similar to the plane) so we can get the waiter's attention without waiting for the right moment to get their attention.
author: isis n.

description: The only other Indian food I had before this was at "Naan-N-Curry" just to let you know ahead of time. Anyway, we were seated immediately and the waiter asked for our order shortly there after. I ordered "Karahi Gosht" (a lamb dish) and "Nimbo Pani" (apparently "their" style of lemonade). I've had lamb before at "N-N-C", but it just doesn't compare to this place. A helluva a lot better over here I gotta say. And the lemonade definitely tasted a little bit more "tart" to it than regular lemonade, but I didn't mind at all. Lessons learned: Don't go to a fast food type place like "Naan-N-Curry" if you want to eat the real thing.
author: Gerard Y.

description: This place was just ok. The servings were relatively small, the food dry, and it took a while for us to get service. For the price, we expected more food, but only got stale naan. Too bad, the reviews were so good but we were thoroughly dissappointed.
author: Leo N.

description:
Rasoi is like the "too nice guy." Always there for you, even on rainy nights, attentive, and covers all the bases, but is sometimes forgotten for more exciting options. The free delivery deal is worth 4 stars alone, but the saag, it has turned me from a saag avoider into a saag lover! Perfect saag. I ask for almost everything spicy, except for the more delicate seafood items, or else they end up leaning a bit toward the unexciting end of the spectrum. The quality and consistency of dishes beats out most other Indian/Pakistani places in the hood too. 
If you're on a budget, they usually have a buy 1, get 1dish 50% off coupon in the weekly, and it's good on deliveries. .
author: Candice L.

description:
Rasoi overall has good food, though I find some of their choices a bit odd (always have to pull the currants out of my veggie samosas, for example). They also (oddly) have some of the City's best chai.
*Update* New owners for Rasoi, and the food is fabulous now.  No more currants in the samosas, for one, and the murgh makhani is over-the-top good.  Probably my favorite Indian restaurant in the City now.
author: Jude F.

description: I came here few months ago and it was good, but not the best. My favorite was the chicken friend like calamari and the lamb naan. And then I heard they got their bar in and they were debuting their cocktail line. So I came back and to my surprise, I love their cocktails!!! Their service improved a lot and the painted the decor more nicely. The bathroom is super duper clean, which is sorta rare in Indian restaurant. The place is huge, so it feels calmer and quieter on weekdays. But back about cocktails... I LOVE the Spiked Mango Lassi with Han Asian Vodka. LOVE IT! And I don't like tamarind, but they made this totally awesome refreshing tamarind martini. I don't know how they made tamarind still taste like tamarind but sweeter. So I gotta give them 5 stars overall after all of these improvements. And drinks. Of course, drinks.
author: dannydan d.

description:
Quiet Monday night, house guests in town, craving Indian food.....voila - best night ever!  

Seriously - you're giving Brick Lane a run for it's money :)  We were curious about the Sauvignon Blanc from India (didn't know they make wine) and the awesome server brought us a few to try!  He also brought us complimentary calamari and yummy chutneys and sauces.  My husband actually said "calamari doesn't get any better than this" and he LOVES his food.  

For six of us we ordered the steak special (incredible green sauce and steak cooked to perfection), lamb vindaloo (with the perfect amount of spice), chicken tikka masala, butter chicken and a shrimp dish.  Of course we ordered naan (the garlic one was to die for), rice and ratai as well.... we had the perfect amount of food to be completely stuffed but without over ordering.  All of the flavours were so incredible - compliments to the chef!  Our server had the perfect balance of being attentive, funny, knowledgeable and helpful without being too fancy or over the top.

This is my new favourite restaurant - as promised - we'll be back!!
author: B P.

description: Met two friends here for an early dinner before going to a show at the Makeout Room, just a few blocks away on 22nd St. We were early and the restaurant was very quiet--more people came in as the evening went on, so don't know if the noise level goes up once more people are in the dining room. I had the chicken korma curry and asked for it mild, but it was too mild--no spice at all. One friend had the chicken masala curry with medium spice--it was about right. The other had the Dal and asked for it spicy and it was! Started with samosas--in a delicious flaky pastry, like a turnover. Had Naan and rice with the meal. Naan was very good. Had to ask for more rice to go with the leftovers we took home and was charged for another serving--thought they could have just added it in for free. But, a nice place in the mission if you are in the mood for something other than Mexican food!
author: Martha L.

description: Delicious! Wonderful, friendly staff. I love the basmati rice, the Chana masala, and the tasty saags.  Mmm. Can't wait to come back soon.
author: Kate A.

description:
last night we cruised on in around 9pm for some delicious indian cuisine.

most of the tables around the perimeter were taken, but there was plenty of tables avail.  now most of the time i eat indian food buffet style.  at least, that's how i normally do it.

the trick here is to go with more than 2 people, the larger your party the more dishes you can order and have a taste of each. actually that's the secret at almost any restaurant.
author: Ameer N.

description:
Overall: 3.5
Been on an Indian kick lately and my travels brought me here via Yelp! and just walked in on a Wednesday night.  Definitely gonna give this place another chance.

Food: 4
I loved that they had a wine from INDIA.  Really!  The mataar paneer was killer but not spicy enough but I can't really blame them. They probably thought I was a white boy so they probably toned it down on the spices. 

Service: 3
The staff was casual and friendly but the server forgot about our appetizer so it's hard to give this place 4 stars.

Decor: 3.5
The decor was cool and a lot nicer and cleaner than most of the other Indian restaurants

Value: 4
It was a little more expensive than other Indian places but the portions were big enough to feed two.
author: Roger H.

description:
I like to consider myself somewhat of a connoisseur of the delights of the Asian sub continent. (In other words, I eat a lot of Indian food.)

This place has some of the most mediocre Indian food I have ever tasted. The nan was scorched, the dishes were bland and the prices were ridiculous. Bad saag paneer for $12? Are you kidding me?

Two stars because the service was really friendly, but with so many great cheap Indian places in San Francisco, I do not plan to come here again.
author: Angie R.

description: My husband and I dined at Aslam's Rasoi yesterday and we believe we found our favorite Indian Restaurant in SF.  The reita was the best we ever had and the chicken Marsala was amazing.  The service was excellent and our waiter Azif was a delight and very helpful.  He even arranged for a taxi when we were ready to leave.
author: Viviane F.

description: The staff was friendly and I really liked the atmosphere. Try the paneer tikka korma. It's delicious. I also really enjoyed the samosas and the goat cheese naan.
author: Nicole M.

description:
Aslam's Rasoi was the inaugural restaurant for my SF Cheap Eats A-Z list, chosen based on the name and yelp reviews. So we were surprised to walk in the door and discover that someone we know works there. Conflict-of-interest disclosed.

It was a slow night, so we were seated quickly and ordered saag aloo and navratan korma with garlic naan and rice. The saag aloo was quite good, as was the naan, but the navratan korma was disappointing. It looked like it was made with pre-cut grocery store vegetables and definitely wasn't as good as some we've had in the past at cheaper restaurants.

When the waiter delivered the order he said, "Here you go ladies........" (us trying not to laugh) "...Oh I mean lady and gentleman, sorry." Profuse apologies followed, but the hilarious ego damage was done. 

If we had been ordering off of the meat menu this place wouldn't have met the cheap criteria. Then again, people seem to really like the meat dishes, so maybe I would've given this place more stars if I were a carnivore.
author: Rachel J.

description:
Aslam's Rasoi has long been one of my favorite Indian restaurants in my area.  

When my friends and I eat there, we inevitably order *far* too much food (because everything is good, so we want some of all of it), so we often save visiting for special occasions.  We made a trip with most of the entire crew (11 of us) this last Saturday evening under the theory of "there are a bunch of birthdays in July, August and September".  Somehow it ended up being mostly my birthday, but well, *shrugs*, presents!  

The staff handled our group wonderfully.  They confirmed the party size and time with me earlier in the day and easily took care of a size change.  They handled a zillion different dishes and everyone ate like happy pigs.  My friends from India confirmed that everything was totally authentic and declared Aslam's their favorite Indian place in the Bay Area.  The kitchen handled our spice range from "white-people spicy" to "I don't want to taste my tongue spicy" and everyone was pleased with what they received.  We even got "surprises" as part of our meal since we were celebrating birthdays.  Unexpected and very charming.

The best part was that they never tried to rush our party.  The restaurant was hopping all night long, but they still let us keep 11 slots from 7:30 to nearly 10:30 when we all started to wander out.  It's rare in San Francisco to find a place that doesn't lean on you to clear a two-top table as quickly as possible, much less letting you hold a whole mess of two-tops for three hours.  It was a perfect night.

Thank you to the staff and kitchen!
author: Elizabeth J.

description: My favorite Indian food restaurant in town. Awesome service and great atmosphere.
author: Juliana B.

description: Had a wonderful meal after a show at The Marsh tonight. Lovely service, comfortable seating - but best of all was the wonderful food. The lamb biryani was particularly killer with the lamb as as tender as any I've had ever. The tandoori prawns were delicious, fresh and perfectly seasoned. We also had the goat cheese naan - well, I don't think goat cheese is supposed to be in naan (ordering wasn't my idea)but it worked and was a nice compliment to the prawns. It may have been a little more expensive than nearby Indian restaurants, but not out of line. I'll be back soon for the tikka masala.
author: liz d.

description: Best indian food in the bay area. I've gone there multiple times and always had an A+ service and food experience.
author: Kanika K.

description:
Love, Love, Love this place!!!!!!!! Amazing!!!!! their masala sauce is unbelievable!!!! Their goat cheese naan are splendid. The service is always exceptional. I always eat their chicken tika masala.

BTW the Staff rocks at this place!!!
author: John C.

description:
Me likey.
I like this place. I used to love going to Indian Oven, and now Indian Oven has come to my neighborhood. Thanks higher power. I try to be good. I am rewarded.
I really like the take on Pakora here. Instead of a dough ball. The ingrediants are deconstructed. Great!!
I love the heat of everything. They are not afraid to light it up. Which is nice. Because "some like it hot"- as the song goes.
Thanks Aslam- you make a mean Daal Sag.
author: shannon t.

description:
My boyfriend had been wanting to take me here for months and we finally got around to it on Saturday September 5th.  My man and his parents have eaten here several times and they are huge food critics.  I was kinda stuck on Masala near 9th Avenue and Lincoln before my most wonderful experience at Aslam's.  

I wanted to give them 4 1/2 stars, but only because we were super hungry and we had to wait a while before having our orders taken.  They were short staffed, so it wasn't really their fault, so I don't feel bad giving them a 5 star review...The server was also really cool and kept apologizing for the wait, so it's all good!  They brought us delicious papadum and that ohhhhh so awesome yogurt and sweet sauce to snack on while we waited for our food.  

My boyfriend ordered a lamb dish (lamb happens to be their specialty) and I ordered the saag paneer (creamed spinach with homemade cheese).  For sides, we had the Pulao (rice), garlic basil naan, goat cheese naan and Mango Chutney.  OMFG!  Best Indian food in SF!
author: Rebecca M.

description:
The food here is pretty good, sometimes even 4-stars.  However, their service is pretty bad.  Despite calling ahead, we waited a long time (1 hour) for a table, during which they consistently said our table was "almost ready".  Once we sat down, nobody stopped by for 15 minutes; we finally had to flag someone down.  Our food took about 45 minutes to come out.  When a friend ordered papadum we asked if they came with any dips and were told they did.  No dips.  The manager came by to apologize several times, but nothing was ever done to improve the service.

Despite the bad service I'll be back for takeout, since they generally get that right.
author: Mike F.

description: Meep! Have I really not written a review for my beloved Aslam's Rasoi yet?!?! Well, I am way past due. My fiancee and I LOVE this place - and we know our Indian food. The spices are great and they are happy to spice it up or tone it down, depending on your preference. Also, it's a great place for a group. I've come here for my birthday (12+ people) and they treated us so well - even with a few picky eaters. I've also brought family here because I know the food is great, service is superb and they can easily accommodate a large party. If I could give it 6 stars, I would!
author: Kalie M.

description:
I don't care how great people may claim your food to be, there is absolutely ZERO excuse for providing poor if not borderline negligent if not borderline abusive (gasp!) service.  Went into this place over a month ago and the service was atrocious. We saw our server once during the evening. It was extremely busy within half an hour of our entering the restaurant...maybe staff some more servers if you're so popular?....The bartender had to refill our friend's pot of tea, which she happened to just pour the entire contents of the pot onto her LEG and not in the cup.  Yes, it was clearly an accident; however, my friend yelped in shock and awe with not even a flinch or remote sense of panic in the clueless bartender's eyes...

Question: You pour scalding water on someone and don't even have the slightest compulsion to say, "I'm so sorry!" and/or run for some ice???  Can we say sadist?

Amazingly, no visit or apology from our server or manager!  

Again, I ask: You pour scalding water on a guest, don't apologize, don't tell the server, don't tell a manager...you just leave the guest to develop blisters and hope she can wear a bikini again without shame.....nice.  

Was there compensation in light of the lack of apology and concern for her welfare? HA! NOTHING was comped from our bill for their attempted disfigurement!!  I was way too embarrassed to let her pay (it was supposed to be her treat), approached our server on a supposed bathroom run, requested he keep the bill at the bar for me to sign, so she wouldn't be roped into paying for her own injury....yet, such a request was obviously too complex for this beacon of culinary delight.....I came out of the bathroom to see her pouring over the bill and my card....where did they get this service staff???? 

I was very annoyed by this experience and even wrote a detailed letter to Aslam's Rasoi, explaining what happened that evening. I was hardly looking for a free meal ticket whatsoever as compensation...call me crazy, but I like to avoid third degree burns when dining out with friends.....not even a simple apology was given. Sad.

Maybe the same reason why they didn't staff enough for that evening is the same reason why they feel no need to apologize for a service mishap...."our food is so good, and the profits are flowing in....who cares if we mangle a few peons during the way."

Just a note: Aslam's Rasoi, I've had better food and service for a fraction of  the price and zero injury. Treat your guests like you appreciate them, not like they should worship you.
author: Jason T.

description: Don't get the overall rating here. The food and service I experienced was mall quality. Food tasted like it came out of a can and was served on cafeteria style plates. Won't be taking my chances again here.
author: Joshua S.

description: I took a few friends from out of town to have dinner here since they were in the mood for Indian and we were going out in the Mission afterwards.  I had never tried this place before (i usually go to udupi palace or dosa) and I was actually pleasantly surprised.  The food was reasonably priced and pretty tasty.  Service was below par, but not so horrible that we walked out.
author: Lisa C.

description:
First time I did a take out of mattar paneer, I was like, did I really pay 10 bucks for this?
Last night, my girlfriends and I celebrated Diwali over dinner. The food was fabulous. Wish they could have more wines that are less pricier and also add a lot more to the desserts menu.
Great food, ambience and service !!!
author: Rashmi V.

description: Went downhill from the appetizers. Their veggie samosas were quite good, but my scallop korma took nearly half an hour to show up (on a Tuesday night... not exactly peak hours) and was underspiced and possibly undercooked. Don't understand the enthusiasm for this place on Yelp.
author: Jeremy E.

description:
UPDATE 12/10: I went back again and it was awesome once again. The Mango Lassi was one of the best ones I've had. I rocked the Karahi Gosht this time but like the lamb dish I got better the first time around. OH, try to sit in the windows because people watching is AWESOME and there are plenty of people to watch and make faces at on Valencia.

I went here on Saturday out of curiosity and came out pleasantly surprised. There was a bit of a wait since there was a large party in the restaurant and I was hungry as hell after walking to Palace Steak House only to find out it was closed for Thanksgiving. Bullshit! But back to the review ....

There was a slight wait, which irritated me, but it was well worth it after the food came out. Our waitress was a daughter of the chef and we just asked her to bring us her favorite dishes. We ended up with the lamb curry (first lamb dish on the menu) and the chicken shish kebab. Both of them were super tasty and crazy delicious with mad props thrown down on the chicken. We kicked things off with the samosa, pompadour and fritter(?) appetizer. My stomach was all like "Oh snaps son! Tasty!"

I don't know why people are hating on Aslam's. Dosa always has a line and I feel like the food is over hyped. It's like my neighbor telling me Taco Bell is the shit. I could care less about "being seen" at a place which is what I feel Dosa is all about. Hell, I better be having a good meal when I am eating out since my personal chef only gets two days off a week. Really, I make him cook hard.

In the end, I felt Aslam's was well worth the price. It might be a bit more expensive than other Indian restaurants in the city but it definitely gained me as a customer. We also scored a free dessert as well since we were so awesome. Dosa where u at?

BATHROOM REVIEW
----------------------------------------
Aslam's had a nice, large bathroom that is unisex. There is plenty of space in the thing if you wanted to join the "I had sex in the restaurant bathroom" club. From what I hear, it is more prestigious than the Mile High Club. But eat at Aslam's knowing you can play Battleship in relative peace and cleanliness when the time calls.
author: Bathrooms Only ..

description: My friend took me to this place and it was the best Indian place I've ever been to. The owner or the owner's son provides the best hospitality to the place. He's really friendly to his guests and provides a good atmosphere. I love the chicken korma and the chicken tikka marsala there. Plus they're mango lassi is the bomb!! Simply delicious. :)
author: Shirley Z.

description: This is THE BEST Pakistani Restaurant in San Francisco. Period. It's less spicy than other Pakistani restaurants in town. Your taste buds will definitely have an orgasm ;-)
author: Amir J.

description: It seemed the food ranged from super spicy (even if you say medium spicy) or bland rice dishes. Mango lassi was too rich & Chicken Biryani was dry and pretty much all rice.  Well, at least the service was attentive.
author: Peg S.

description:
Perfect North Indian comfort food. Hands down my favorite in SF.

The highlights here are the naan and vegetarian curries. All of these are excellent: Bhindi Masala (okra), Saag Aloo (spinach with potatoes), Dal Saag (spinach and lentils), Navrattan Korma (mixed veggies, nuts, fruits) and Paneer Tikka Korma (think Chicken Tikka Masala but with cheese instead of chicken).

My favorite dish is probably the Kashmiri Biryani, although the fact that it includes raisins and other fruit makes it an acquired taste.

On the meat side of the menu, the Chicken Tikka Masala is just OK. The Seekh Kebab (ground lamb) however is excellent.

When they ask for spiciness, "medium" is a good balance. "Medium-hot" is about my limit.

I will say that service, drinks and atmosphere are not their strong points: you go here for the food, first and foremost. This is a great takeout option as well if you are in the neighborhood.
author: Matt B.

description:
how have i not tried this place until now?

sooo, sooo yummy! probably the best naan i've ever had (we had the garlic/basil, goat cheese and plain) and the food was nice and spicy.

i thought the dishes were a little expensive (about $15/ea), but they're big servings. good for leftovers, but not so good for a small party who wants to try a variety of things.

we ordered to-go, but the staff seemed very friendly. i'm looking forward to eating in next time. i'll definitely be back!
author: Kristen A.

description:
The Chicken Tikki Masala is truly fantastic, the chicken chunks not swimming in fat globules, the sauce just medium spicy the way I liked it.  My boyfriend said his Chicken Vindaloo was spiced just right.  The Naan was amazing, we tried both garlic and regular, and the mango chutney was sweet and sticky, just the way it ought to be!  My only one grievance was portion size, although that may be a good thing!

I never would have eaten at this restaurant because it is sort of out of my way but our friend lives in the Mission and so now we are in love with this restaurant.  Since we spend so much time in the city, now we know where to go for a sure-fire meal and yummy take-away.  

The restaurant itself is lovely and I absolutely loved the tables, each one seemed to be hand painted with a different design.  The lights were low, the wine list was adequate and the wait staff was just only a tiny bit slow, but it was quite busy at 9:30 at night, so that isn't too bad.  A great restaurant.
author: Gabrielle C.

description: This has always been my favorite Indian in the city.  I've been going here for about 7 years, even before Aslam took over.  When he did, he brought along his family to help him run the place.  It was through building a relationship with this wonderful group of people that elevated the taste of the food for me.  The food is as authentic as the service.  It's a great date spot without the pretension of something like Dosa.
author: Andy S.

description:
Here's the deal:  They'll make your curry as hot as you want it- and when they say hot they mean DAMN HOT... like please-get-me-a-glass-of-milk NOW hot. Incredible!  Service is good, were served complementary dessert (not my favorite, but hey) and they have CAKEBREAD wine on the menu.  5 stars for red hot vindaloo and 5 stars for CAKEBREAD. 

yes, it was a little cold inside and yes it was a little pricier than most- though markedly cheaper and better than Gaylord's.  Give it a try.
author: Jenni D.

description: Really good Indian food...in fact, at the top of my list! Also, the beautiful restaurant and super awesome staff make it that much better!! When I want Indian food in SF, there's a damn good chance I'll be going to Aslam's!!! Enjoy!
author: kyle w.

description:
we went here for my good friend's birthday dinner... a party of 13. i'm guessing the experience would have been a little bit better if they didn't have to account for 13 people. 

all in all, the food was great. probably some of the best garlic naan i have ever tasted. the rice was perfectly spiced, and our vegetable dish was not overcooked or soggy. i even tried some of my friends' dishes and all around the food tasted great. 

i was splitting with my boyfriend and he wanted to go easy on the spicy... but i love the spicy. i asked for a spicy chile sauce on the side, but it never came. a little shy on the water rounds. also, our reservation was for 8pm and our table wasn't ready until about 830. however, we were offered a complimentary bottle of wine.

the table across from us ordered a gigantic bottle of wine (no joke, maybe the size of a football) and they offered us refills. that was pretty fun. 

fun environment, catchy tunes, and minimalist decor with a great color scheme. perfect for a relaxed dinner with friends. 

parking is a beach.
author: Romana H.

description:
For the price, I thought this place was just... A-OK. We had to order 4 orders of naan AND rice .. which got to be really pricey really quick =__= I'd think it's more complimentary for the price but eh I am a cheapass so that's probably just me. 

Tandoori Chicken (full): I'm not a huge fan of Tandoori Chicken because it always just feels really tough and dry for me. This was the same; I didn't really eat it because it just looked tough and dry, but I think it tasted better than it looked. my mom really enjoyed this one though so this is probably just biased.

Chicken Tikka Masala: Cant go wrong with my favorite Indian dish. Definitely one of the best I've had... but i'm not very picky with my chicken tikka masala and I"ve never paid 13 for it. It was the first time I ordered it spicy and it was actually spicy, though.

Lamb Vindaloo: Not very satisfactory, and my famfam agreed. We ordered medium because Vindaloo is naturally spicy but it was not spicy. It looked like a brown plate of goop, and it tasted alright but wouldn't order it again

Naan is good but again, pretty small. I just thought this place was not worth it.. but it was definitely one of the "better" (I mean quality wise) indian places I"ve been to, especially in comparison to the places around Berkeley. However, I still think I'd rather pay $10 for naan & tikka masala than 16 for both =_= good meal though
author: Leah K.

description: This review is on my dad's behalf. I took my parents here because they in town visiting and after a couple weeks of dining out they wanted northern indian cuisine. My dad fell in love with the food. The service was also really good and we ended up getting a dish on the house. The host/waiter, Asif, (the owner's son) actually remembered me from a couple months ago down to the day and what I ordered! My parents chatted it up with him regarding the restaurant and what he does. I have a bunch of food left over to munch on tomorrow... definitely a place to try... I love me some butter naan and chicken korma!
author: Dalia M.

description:
Despite the fact that it's just fancy enough to attract the yupp-factor on weekend evenings, for which I must dock one star, this is my current favorite Pakistani/Indian restaurant.

When I lived at 17th and Guerrero, I frequented the cheap, hole-in-the-wall Pakistani/Indian places around there.  But the last few times I've been, the food has been increasingly more greasy and the restaurants have been increasingly more busy than normal. (Is there a relationship? I do not know.)  I'm happy for them and glad they're getting more business, but since I've moved, it's more of a trek for me to get up there, and one that I'm less likely to make if it will be hit or miss once I get there.

Aslam's is a bit pricier, between $9 and $14 for a dish as opposed to between $5 and $8, but I find it to be worth it.  I've never had a bad dish, and I've been enough times and with enough people to try quite a few.  Favorites include their Chicken Korma, Keema Aloo Mattar, and Aloo Saag. (All their spinach dishes are really good, I think because they like mince the spinach especially a lot, or something.) 

Last time, I took my very-extroverted-waitress-from-Austin friend who was in town, and she got palsy enough with our waiter that he brought us a free bowl of kheer for dessert, which was a nice touch.

It's probably a good precaution to make a reservation, especially on the aforementioned yuppified weekend nights, although they've always been able to seat me even without reservations.
author: Megan D.

description:
Sorry, Yelpers, I've been lurking too long. Just wrote a negative review, so I want to balance out with a place that I love. And that would be Aslam Rasoi.

Everybody has their benchmark dish. Mine, for Indian food, is Sag Paneer. Wherever I go to a new Indian place I order up Sag Paneer. For SF, Gaylord's Sag is delicate, Naan 'N Curry is intense, Pakwan is value priced. As for Aslam Rasoi, well they're in a class by itself. I haven't had Sag this good since London. 

But, wait there's more. Aslam is the only Indian/Pakistani place I've ever been to that serves up Calamari Pakoras (what they call Bombay Pakoras -  perhaps, if I had spent more time in Mumbai). Now, Calamari is my ultimate benchmark dish. You see, my former love thang co-authored a Calamari cookbook and was co-owner of the now defunct India Joze (of Santa Cruz fame), which had a yearly Calamari Festival. In fact, their side street was renamed "Squid Row". So, I think I've learned a thing or two about the pleasures of fried cephalopods. The first is that almost every restaurant over cooks it - to the point of having the texture of shoe leather. Some chefs call it al dente; I call it inedible. Not Aslam Rasoi. Tender juicy morsels. Ahhhhh... those were the days. Ok, my stomach is growling. Time to phone in an order. This review is soooo over!
author: iko o.

description: Good food, great service and decent prices. Awesome naan.
author: Robert W.

description:
The reviews posted about Aslam's Rasoi are hard for me to understand. I've lived in this city for five years, and I've eaten at many, many Indian restaurants: Clay Oven, Bombay India in the Castro, Dosa, Masala in the sunset, Pakwan (which is not Indian, I know), Naan-N-Curry (both locations), and many more in London, Boston, and Chicago. 

I have been to Aslam's at least seven times, and I must say, their food is outstanding! Their chicken and lamb tikka are the most tender, flavorful, and succulent of their kind that I have tasted at any Indian restaurant, period. Their curries are spiced with more nuance and subtlety than you'll find in most Indian restaurants (try their daal, karahi gosht, and lamb madras). Their curries are balanced and complex, unique in that they don't drown out the natural flavor of the meat. 

It perplexes me that people aren't raving about the food at this place. Since it's a fairly new restaurant, one has to expect that they'll be working out kinks in the service (and reviewers are right - service can be great or missing), and, yes, the place does want for ambiance. Still, the elegance of their food - and the near perfection of its preparation - make Aslam's a gem in the Mission. Don't miss out!
author: Mike T.

description:
And, just like that, I have a favorite Indian food place in SF now. 

Say what you will about being overpriced - the difference is a few dollars at most, but the difference in quality is simply amazing. Chicken tika masala (yeah, cliche, but I was craving it!) was gorgeously spiced. The Tandoori chicken was so tender and juicy. 

But the fifth star really is for the service. Our waiter was friendly, helpful, and funny. The food arrived quickly (though it also wasn't very busy late on a weeknight).

Overall, a great experience and can't wait to make this place a regular eat-out destination.
author: Christie C.

description:
totally legit.

My boyfriend and I went here on a total spur-of-the-moment date... We were just going to go to Papalote for some burritos but he had that for lunch... so we sort of just wandered around the mission until we came across Aslam's Rasoi. It was between that and Dosa, but Dosa was really crowded and I felt like trying something new.

The food was truly flavorful and filling and the wait staff was really friendly. It was a bit pricey but i thought it was worth it.
The only reason why I took off a star was because my food was SO SO SO SPICY and I kept trying to ask a waiter for some yoghurt sauce but they kept walking by and not paying any attention to our table! They didn't come by to ask how everything was either, so I didn't have that opportunity to ask them for any... my boyfriend had to wave someone down and even then it took like... 10 minutes for them to bring it to me. I also ran out of water in the waiting period... never a good feeling when your tongue is burning off.

Despite the whole mouth burning, eyes watering incident, I really enjoyed the restaurant. I'd go back... I'll just ask for some yoghurt sauce beforehand.
author: Felicity M.

description:
First of all, this place is great for a group! They have a big space, which is really hard to find in the Mission.

The food was great, as was the service (even though I had to ask for lemon like 4 times). I highly recommend the samosas, which were as close to homemade as I've had in the city. No frozen wonton wrappers here! The spicy potato fries appetizer was also very yummy - we should have ordered 2! Next time we will. 

The dishes also seem to be served family style, so that makes it an even better place for going with a group.

Have I mentioned that if you are dining with more then 3 people, you should go here?
author: Shal J.

description:
If I could give it 2.5 stars for acceptably average, I would.

I ate an early dinner last night - had the Aloo Mutter and Chicken Tikka, rice, glass of wine.

I heard this was one of the best Indian places in the City, sorry to say it's just a bit more upscale looking than most.

Service was jovial, and quick. Food came ultra-fast.

The Aloo Mutter was good, not great. The Chicken Tikka left quite a bit to be desired.

Chutney still tops my list.
author: Nathan W.

description:
This is the best Indian food I've ever had.  I've only been once, so not sure about consistency, but boy was it good the night I was there! The ingredients were amazingly fresh tasting and not a single dish failed to delight.

It was slow night, and service was excellent.
author: E F.

description: Good food and service. Nice tables for four near the window. I ordered the prawns in a coconut type sauce at a level of hot, which was really good (you choose your "level of hotness"). If applicable, ask for the alcoholic drink menu.  My date did not get one and she left thinking they didn't serve wine, which would've gone well with her plate.
author: Isaac G.

description: Delicious! But watch out, it is SPICY! Even their mild is spicy for a spice wimp like me, and my bfriend who loves spicy was SWEATING through his "spicy" prawn vindaloo and told me that "medium" will do just fine next time. Their Chicken Tikka Masala was the creamiest and best sauce I've ever had so that is must.   But their Dal Saag and Saag Paneer were so so - I like my cheese cubes to be more tender and theirs were more fried and cooked.  But other than that, every thing was delicious and the space was nice and not a scary hole in the wall.
author: Barndi K.

description: We came here for my Birthday with a party of 25. The whole evening was handled very gracefully by the wait staff and everyone was impressed with the food. It's a tough thing to serve groups and I have to say we really put these guys to the test in terms of numbers, well done.
author: Stacey C.

description: This is a fantastic restaurant!  Amazing, flavorful food and excellent service! I had the curry lamb dish (forgot exact name if the plate) and the lamb kebab (called "seekh kebab). MMMMMMM!
author: Bassam A.

description: It was packed, but we got a seat for two quickly.  The appetizers were perfect for sharing and the lamb and the Tandori Chicken were both worth there weight in gold.  Loved, Loved, Loved the garlic and basil Nana and the service was spot on, our waiter never missed a beat.  I can't wait to take my family there!!!!!
author: Rikki S.

description: Best Indian food in the city. Prices are reasonable and anything from the tandoor is great quality and authentic.
author: Anuj S.

description:
Fantastic ambiance, impeccible service...... and the food?  Yes, that was out of this world.

My uncle travels to India often, and claims this to be his favorite and most authentic Indian food he's found in the US.  The entire experience was fabulous and we'll return many times!
author: Kyra W.

description:
The service is spectacular and it's very easy to become a regular.   I don't know if I would consider Aslam's *the best* Indian food I've ever had but it is certainly the friendliest place I have EVER eaten.

I head here on a casual week night, or when I don't feel like cooking but certainly not for date night. 

I really do love the service though.
author: Krissy M.

description: I'm so excited that I found another great Indian restaurant to bring out-of-towners and to regularly dine out.  The food here is very delicious.  While the hubby and I were not crazy about the Lamb Rogan Josh, garlic naan and Mango Lassi, we absolutely loooooooooved the CTM, Saag Paneer, Onion Kulcha, and Nimbo Pani.  The decor is fabulous.  The service was a bit slow.  Normally I would have given this place a solid 4 stars, but I'm giving this place five stars because of Asif!!!!  You rock and we look forward to seeing you soon!!!
author: C L.

description: Nice interior and great tasty food. Though my group of 6 people had to wait about half hour before the main dishes came.
author: Steven T.

description:
I really enjoy Indian food but I haven't eaten much of it since I left my old company (in 2006) where I had many Indian friends who either went out to eat (at Indian Buffets) or more often, they'd bring in home cooked food to share. They were amazing cooks!! Anyway, my SF Indian dining experience has been limited to Naan and Curry and Tikka Masala. 

I had a great time at Aslams, delicious food + friendly and efficient service + nice decor makes it a pretty happening place. Best of all, the food wasn't oily and my tummy was happy. 

It's a very large restaurant and pretty close to packed the entire time we were there. I look forward to going back here again!
author: Mellie D.

description: Really awesome place. The Seekh Kababs are really good. I have had great Indian food at lot of places especially in India, but their Seekh Kababs rank with some of the best I have ever had.
author: Rahul K.

description:
I'm yet another person who doesn't understand the negative reviews of Aslam's Rasoi. I've been here twice and thoroughly enjoyed both visits. Maybe the pre- and post-Aslam reviews should be placed in separate Yelp entries?

Tonight, we enjoyed the Rasoi rogan josh (lamb curry), chana masala (garbanzo beans), and bhindi masala (okra) with rice and garlic naan. Everything was tasty and well-prepared. We asked for the food to be medium spicy, and it was definitely hot enough to pleasantly heat up our mouths and keep us drinking water -- in a good way. The lamb was tender, its sauce deep and complex. The garbanzo beans were nicely cooked, not hard as they often are in other places. (Does everyone prepare theirs from scratch, or do some places use canned?) The okra was cut into short strips and fried, a very different kind of preparation than what I've had from Al Hamra.

On our previous visit, we had the saag paneer (spinach with cheese cubes), bengan bartha (eggplant), and tandoori prawns, all of which were great, but I can't describe that meal in as much detail, as it was several months ago.

Service on our first visit was a bit disorganized, and it was definitely better this time around. Everyone was friendly, although I noticed our server on both visits, a guy with longish hair pulled back in a ponytail and sideburns, kept trying to sell us appetizers and drinks. Slightly irksome but not a big deal. Atmosphere is totally mellow. I like the bhangra music.

Go here, it's good! Don't believe the negative reviews. It's not as cheap as Pakwan, Naan 'n' Curry, and other places of that ilk, but the food is also that much better.
author: Tara M.

description:
This place defines 3/5 stars. The setting is great and interesting. The service is...not so great - there was 1 waiter serving the whole restaurant the night we were there...but that stuff doesn't usually influence my review

The food, which does, was exactly what 3/5 stars should be in Indian food. It is good, it is slightly about average...in fact it's 6/10 (wait...) But really, it's nothing special. Better Indian food can be had at several places around the Bay Area. My chicken vindaloo was spicy (asked for 7/10 spicy-ness). But it was...flat. There wasn't too much depth. The chicken itself didn't say anything. The sauce was...a bit boring. Oh and they charged extra for rice! lame! On the brighter side, the garlic naan was pretty awesome and the samosas were good.

So...3/5 for this place. Not 2.9/5 or 3.1/5. Just 3/5.
author: Tolga E.

description:
In the battle of the two Indian restaurants in each other's lap's on Valencia Steet, Aslam's is the clear winner for me.  It's spicier.  I really don't get all the hype about Dosa - to me, all that spicey, saucy food is wasted without lots of delicious naan to soak it up.  Plus Dosa is overcrowded and I felt rushed there.  Anyway, on to our subject - I showed up at Aslam's after the bar, lateish, and was amazed and extremely grateful to land some tender, juicy chicken tikka.

Update - have to give Aslam's five stars.  It doesn't get enough hype - this place is consistently great.  It creeps up on you - you keep trying other Indian spots, and they're great, but Aslam's is where it's at.
author: Natalie S.

description:
4.5 stars. I had a really great experience here. 

Nice atmosphere, delectable dishes, very friendly service.

 We started with the chicken samosas and shared the tilapia curry, chicken tikka masala, prawn vindaloo, daal, along with paratha, garlic and basil naan and plain naan. I tend not to choose seafood when I order Indian and Pakistani food. Aslam's Rasoi has changed me. The tilapia curry was unbelievably yummy. Very creamy and flavorful. Probably my favorite of the night. But everything else we had was also delicious. The cold Chimay on tap was the perfect accompaniment to our spicy meal. We were stuffed but very very happy.

Can't wait to go back.
author: Jenny K.

description: Excellent food.  We had takeout so can't speak for the service. Lamb Vindaloo was very spicy, tasted of distinct fresh spices, not a muddled pre-mixed spice combination. Chicken Tikka Masala was well done also, balanced spice level. "Hot" was properly hot, and "Medium" was as well. Small portions on the entrees, but still a good value.
author: M J.

description:
BEST Chana Masala I've ever had. Different from the way other places do it, but I absolutely love it. Chicken tikka also fantastic, creamier than usual.

Service is great; I've never had to wait for a table. (The place is rarely full, for some reason. Usually nice and quiet.) Had a red wine (Syrah I think) from India that was a perfect complement to all the spicy food.
author: Kelly R.

description: Always reliable, solid food.  Good service.  Good atmosphere.  Very grown up place to go.  It isn't over run with throngs of people.  You can hear your dinner companion speak.
author: Jules a.

description:
This place is a fantastic find.  I agree with another reviewer here in that it is hard for me to remember the exact name of this place, but I certainly know where it is.

I have gone a few times now and feel like it is the best Indian place in SF for several reasons.  The servers know what they are doing and truly wonderful.  From the sauces to the meats, you can taste the quality of food you are being served.  Usually, Indian restaurants that serve quality food also tend towards smaller menus with many things unfamiliar to the standard Indian fare.  Personally, I don't seek food because it is unusual, I am very happy enjoying the food that I love and they certainly have a strong menu that features familiar flavors and more.

The space is also quite nice.  A cozy atmosphere is the exception to Indian fare in SF and the price is as reasonable as any other.  It is nice to find a place that inspires me enough to get back on Yelp.  It has been a while.
author: Ian E.

description:
I really enjoyed the food here. Absolutely everything we had was fantastic. At times the food seemed to be a bit TOO flavorful, but I couldn't tell if we had just picked a bad wine to go with our meal. (BUT I had leftovers today and it was absolutely fantastic!)

The service was excellent. We had servers coming to check on our water and if we needed anything else just the right amount of time during our entire meal. At one point the busboy tipped over a container of some sweet dipping sauce (pardon my ignorance for not knowing what it is) ALL over my velvet bag. No worries for me - just a bag - but i think half the entire staff of the restaurant came over to apologize. I think the guy that actually knocked it over was on the verge of tears. It was quite endearing. I'd definitely make my way back again.
author: Karva S.

description:
Last night I was with a friend in the Mission trolling for food.  We passed Aslam's Rasoi and since we both love all things Indian/Pakastani, we decided to eat there.  

We walk in and I start to pick up a menu.  Out crawls a little roach!  We immediately left.

Let's be clear, I'm from NY where the roach is the state animal, and I've been watching Gordon Ramsay's Kitchen Nightmares (he's so HOT, but I digress), however I don't want to see one when I'm about to eat.  I will not revisit.
author: Jean C.

description:
Solid Indian food, but overpriced w/ small portions.

I like this place fine, and generally stuff is pretty tasty here, but for Indian food at this level, it's just too pricey.

The Samosas and pakoras are all good, nice flavor and not too greasy.

The Tandoori chicken is very tender, but a few little pieces of chicken tikka for $14 is far above standard for Indian places.  The mixed tandoori at $18 gives you just little pieces of a handful of things.

The chicken, lamb, and paneer dishes are all very tasty and they do a good job at matching your desired spice levels.  However, at $12-14 per entree, the curry dishes are pretty small - not at all what you'd expect at an Indian place like this.

I've tried a couple of the seafood dishes and wasn't really impresed, but I'm generally not into seafood at Indian places.

The naans are quite good, a little better than average Indian places.

Overall, I like this place fine, but find the check to be about 50% higher than comparable places like Mehfil (where I actually like the food slightly better as well).
author: Deva H.

description:
Hubby and I came here for dinner after being informed that a wait for a table at DOSA would be at least an hour. We were initially skeptical about the quality of the food due to the fact that the restaurant was half full while the neighboring restaurants were bursting with patrons. Starving for food, we decided to take a chance. 

Aside from the slow service (took us 30 minutes to get the attention of the wait staff and place our order) the quality of the food was extremely good. Hubby ordered the lamb curry and I ordered the chicken with spinach. The meat in both dishes were extremely tender and flavorful. We also ordered the keeman naan, which was delectable and not as greasy as other indian establishments. 

Overall, very satisfied.
author: Sandy Y.

description:
Best Indian/Pakistani restaurant in the Mission for the price.
Lots of vegetarian options and dinner specials.
Dosa has spicier food but is much less affordable than Aslam's.
author: Raina M.

description: Ok Aslams....we cheated on you tonight and went to DOSA on Fillmore.  We SO much more enjoy your food!  My husband is a connoisseur of Indian and he is right on this one...ASLAMS IS THE BEST.  The food by far is tastier and better here and we will not stray again.  The ambiance is nice...but the food doesn't compare.  See you soon...
author: K S.

description: I needed to have better communication with the staff. They did not bother to connect with me in a timely matter which actually caused much more chaos in my life than they realized. Flakiness may work for many Californians, but not for a respectful, responsible, and communicative person.
author: San Francisco C.

description: Delicious and attentive service.  They even provided candles and helped serve my husband's bday cheesecake that we brought for dessert.  Our kids love watching the kitchen through the window, so we always request the booth in front of the kitchen.
author: Amy F.

description:
This is not what I would consider good Indian Food. The thing is that I sometimes enjoy Americanized Indian Food, but I can't really say that this would be a good version of that either. However I must include that I am a vegetarian, and I cannot try their non-veg dishes, so I can't say much for that. I had the bhindi masala (okra curry). Normally I like Indian okra pan fried, but the curry was very greasy, and it did not have any good flavor. Also, I know how much people love Naan (me included). The naan ended up being SOUR! It also was very thin and chewy instead fluffy the way it should be. 

This restaurant has some redeeming qualities. The service was great with a really friendly staff. Its a nice looking restaurant--relatively nice ambiance. I had an appetizer salad which I definitely enjoyed. It was very fresh with a nice light dressing. Considering that this is an Indian/Pakistani restaurant I'm not so sure salad is what one looks for. Overall, its somewhere I would go to out of convenience but rather not go out of my way for.
author: Kavitha V.

description: Food is so good here...the Chicken Tikka is so well marinated...it is a bit pricey but the food is delicious
author: Veronica G.

description: Asif is the best! We have had great service on numerous occassions. Their food is well priced. I highly recommend the appetizers. Try one or all, its a great addition to the authentic Indian meal.
author: Laura L.

description:
okay third freakin review but I am pleased to say that Aslam Rasoi is alive and well, and by my vote, the best Indian restaurant in the city. Hands down. I have yet to leave an Indian restaurant not feeling super heavy and greecified but Aslam does the job.
